title: How to Contact the Social Security Administration by Phone, Email, and More

steps.title: Call toll-free at 1-800-772-1213[1] X Trustworthy Source US Social Security Administration Independent U.S. government agency that administers Social Security and related information Go to source any time for automated services.
steps.content: Call toll-free at 1-800-772-1213 [1] X Trustworthy Source US Social Security Administration Independent U.S. government agency that administers Social Security and related information Go to source any time for automated services. Automated telephone services can be used 24 hours a day to get information and to conduct some types of business. [2] X Trustworthy Source US Social Security Administration Independent U.S. government agency that administers Social Security and related information Go to source Automated services include but are not limited to requesting a benefit verification letter, requesting a replacement Medicare Card, asking for a benefit claim status, and finding the address of the local Social Security office. You can listen to informational services on payment delivery dates, direct deposit, taxes, fraud, and supplemental security income.

steps.title: Call 1-800-772-1213 from Monday to Friday to speak to a representative.
steps.content: Call 1-800-772-1213 from Monday to Friday to speak to a representative. If you wish to handle personal information that cannot be handled via the automated services, call between 7am and 7pm in your local time during the week.

steps.title: Email the Social Security support team.
steps.content: Email the Social Security support team. Most Social Security services are now accessible on the internet. To contact Social Security by email, use the following webpage: https://secure.ssa.gov/emailus/ . Using email, you can apply for Social Security benefits, request a replacement card, or receive a Social Security statement. [3] X Research source Personal information requests must be handled over the phone and not over email.

steps.title: Call into your local Social Security office.
steps.content: Call into your local Social Security office. You can get application forms and find out information from a customer service representative at your local office. Use the Social Security office locator to find out where your local office is by typing in your ZIP code. [4] X Trustworthy Source US Social Security Administration Independent U.S. government agency that administers Social Security and related information Go to source The locator can be found here: https://www.ssa.gov/locator/ .

steps.title: Write a letter to the Social Security offices.
steps.content: Write a letter to the Social Security offices. If you don't think your problem can be solved by another method of communication, you can write a letter. Social Security advises that you only write a letter if none of the other methods have worked for you. In the letter, include your Social Security Number and your claim. [5] X Trustworthy Source US Social Security Administration Independent U.S. government agency that administers Social Security and related information Go to source The address of the office is: Social Security Administration, Office of Public Inquiries, 1100 West High Rise, 6401 Security Blvd., Baltimore, MD 21235.

steps.title: Use the frequently asked questions page to quickly find an answer.
steps.content: Use the frequently asked questions page to quickly find an answer. While it's not a comprehensive list, many answers can also be found on the frequently asked questions page, which can be found here: https://faq.ssa.gov/en-US/ . Using the frequently asked questions page can be a lot easier and a lot quicker than using any of the other methods.

steps.title: Arrange an appointment.
steps.content: Arrange an appointment. Call Social Security at 1-800-325-0778 [6] X Trustworthy Source US Social Security Administration Independent U.S. government agency that administers Social Security and related information Go to source or, write a letter to Social Security Administration, Office of Public Inquiries, 1100 West High Rise, 6401 Security Blvd., Baltimore, MD 21235, or visit a local office. [7] X Trustworthy Source US Social Security Administration Independent U.S. government agency that administers Social Security and related information Go to source Social Security will provide deaf or hard of hearing people with free assistance and services, or you can bring your own interpreter if they are over 18.

steps.title: Choose your method of communication.
steps.content: Choose your method of communication. To communicate at your appointment, you can choose from a variety of options: [8] X Trustworthy Source US Social Security Administration Independent U.S. government agency that administers Social Security and related information Go to source Use a qualified sign language interpreter. Use handwritten notes. Lip-read what the Social Security representative says. Use telephone devices for the deaf. Bring your own interpreter such as a friend or family member. Social Security cannot permit the use of an interpreter younger than 18.

steps.title: Cancel or reschedule your appointment.
steps.content: Cancel or reschedule your appointment. If you can’t make your appointment or you need to move it to a different date, call the TTY number 1-800-325-0778 toll-free from 7am to 7pm, Monday to Friday. [9] X Trustworthy Source US Social Security Administration Independent U.S. government agency that administers Social Security and related information Go to source

steps.title: Locate a Social Security Administration office nearby.
steps.content: Locate a Social Security Administration office nearby. You can do this by visiting their office locator at https://secure.ssa.gov/ICON/main.jsp . Type in your local zip code and then click “Locate.” The address of the Social Security Office closest to you will pop up, as well as their hours. [10] X Trustworthy Source US Social Security Administration Independent U.S. government agency that administers Social Security and related information Go to source Most offices will be open Monday-Friday from 9am-4pm and closed on the weekends, but it’s important to read the hours for your local office just to make sure.

steps.title: Schedule an appointment to visit the office, if possible.
steps.content: Schedule an appointment to visit the office, if possible. You may not be able to get an appointment for several weeks (or even months). If you’re dealing with an urgent matter, definitely check to see if an appointment time is available, but be prepared to go right into the office. [11] X Research source To schedule an appointment, you’ll need to call the SSA’s main phone number. You could schedule an appointment to apply for a replacement Social Security number card.

steps.title: Visit the office whenever possible if you don't make an appointment.
steps.content: Visit the office whenever possible if you don't make an appointment. Social Security offices are always busy, and it’s likely that you’ll have to wait for a long time to be helped. Plan ahead and either get there right when they open or make sure you arrive several hours before the office is scheduled to close. [12] X Research source Check the office’s hours to make sure you’re arriving at the right time. You can go right to the office if you need to handle matters such as filing for benefits or appealing a disability decision.

steps.title: Go to the local embassy.
steps.content: Go to the local embassy. The United States has embassies all over the world. The Social Security Office of Earnings and International Operations is assisted by embassies around the world. The nearest embassy will be able to help you with your Social Security problem. [13] X Trustworthy Source US Social Security Administration Independent U.S. government agency that administers Social Security and related information Go to source A list of United States embassies can be found at: https://www.ssa.gov/foreign/foreign.htm . If you can’t find an embassy listed for the country you’re in, contact the embassy of a neighboring country by phone.

steps.title: Write to the Social Security Field Office.
steps.content: Write to the Social Security Field Office. If you are not receiving benefits and you would like to find out if you are eligible, write to the following address: Social Security Administration, Office of Earnings and International Operations, P.O. Box 17775, Baltimore, Maryland 21235-7775, United States of America. [14] X Trustworthy Source US Social Security Administration Independent U.S. government agency that administers Social Security and related information Go to source You should also write to this address if you or a family member are receiving benefits and you would like to report a change in status such as death, illness, marriage, or divorce.

steps.title: Contact the Social Security service by phone.
steps.content: Contact the Social Security service by phone. Using the following webpage https://www.ssa.gov/foreign/foreign.htm , find your nearest embassy and call them using the number listed. You will need to pay for the call. [15] X Trustworthy Source US Social Security Administration Independent U.S. government agency that administers Social Security and related information Go to source

steps.title: Use another online Social Security service to solve your problem.
steps.content: Use another online Social Security service to solve your problem. On the following website, https://www.ssa.gov/foreign/ , you can apply for retirement benefits or disability services, or you can use either the benefit eligibility screening tool, or the future benefits tool. [16] X Trustworthy Source US Social Security Administration Independent U.S. government agency that administers Social Security and related information Go to source You can also download a number of application forms including the disability report form, the special benefits for World War II Veterans form, or the Social Security card application form.
